Can we use one of the enums for more descriptive status codes please, e.g. HttpStatusCode.SERVER_ERROR rather than 500.

Imho, I prefer explicit error codes rather than indirecting through yet another 3rd party dependency. Constants files are great for constants that might change in the future, but HTTP status codes are never going to change.
But.. in the interests of an easy life, I don't mind changing it.
We can't use the Jetty error code constants as Jetty is going away.
I guess we could org.apache.HttpStatus which is currently being dragged in anyway.

nodes.bodyText: Why is the plugin handler failing the context? This seems to contradict the expectation that implementations of AuthenticationPlugin should end the response if the user fails to authenticate.
Previously the plugin was ending the response, which seemed wrong to me (as per our previous discussion) so I changed the contract, so now it's Vert.x that does this.
Can we update the Java docs in AuthenticationPlugin and the test implementation (in this repo) to reflect that? The fact that the two were incongruous threw me off.

Before this refactor, handleError() was populating the status code and providing a message when ending the response, but the new code that previously called this method does not. Was this a conscious decision? I think it's nice to populate the response because otherwise failures appear silent from curl (and probably other tools as well?).
Not sure I follow.. could you elaborate a bit?

Could you point me to the routingContext.fail() line you are referring to? There are probably a few places in the code that call that :)
RoutingContext fail will cause the failureHandler to be called, and the failure handler should send back the correct error response (depending on the kind of failure).
Ah I see, and both the regular failure handler (in ServerVerticle) and the old API failure handler (in PortedEndpoints) set the status code and message, so we should be good. Thanks for clarifying!
Right, the change here basically centralises all the failure handling in one place so we don't end responses with failure from multiple places any more, which makes it a bit simpler to manage.
Why is this public?
No particular reason, I'm usually make classes public by default unless there's a very good reason not to.
Why is this public?
As above
